pullRequest.title: [MCP23017] Allow choosing I2C bus numbers other than 0 and 1
pullRequest.bodyText:
[MCP23017] Allow choosing I2C bus numbers other than 0 and 1

If additional I2C busses have to be used because of a limitation of 8 MCP23017 on the same bus (8 available addresses) those additional bus numbers should be chooseable. It is only nescessary to add further options in the GUI

commit.message:
Update thing-types.xml

If additional I2C bit banging busses are used, those addtional bus numbers are nescessary

Signed-off-by: Jockra <59808296+Jockra@users.noreply.github.com>

commit.message:
support all busses + description

Raspberry supports up to 7 I2C busses. Description added

Signed-off-by: Jockra <59808296+Jockra@users.noreply.github.com>

nodes.bodyText: Please use a new line for each sentence. I also don't understand what excatly is needed to enable the overlays. Is this just a configuration option the user has to set?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -4,6 +4,9 @@ This binding allows you to have native access for MCP23017 I/O expander on I2C b
 It was tested with Raspberry Pi 2 and Raspberry Pi 3, but probably should work with other devices supported by [Pi4J](https://pi4j.com/) library.
 
 On Raspberry Pi the user on which openHAB is running (default user name is "openhab") needs to be added to groups "i2c" and  "gpio".
+As the MCP23017 has 3 address pins, you are restricted to 8 devices on a I2C bus.
+To use more devices you have to open further I2C busses. Therefore you can use overlays to enable bit banging I2C busses on the Raspberry Pi connector, up to I2C6.

nodes.bodyText: Thanks. That makes it more clear

 It was tested with Raspberry Pi 2 and Raspberry Pi 3, but probably should work with other devices supported by [Pi4J](https://pi4j.com/) library.
 
 On Raspberry Pi the user on which openHAB is running (default user name is "openhab") needs to be added to groups "i2c" and  "gpio".
+As the MCP23017 has 3 address pins, you are restricted to 8 devices on a I2C bus.
+To use more devices you have to open further I2C busses. Therefore you can use overlays to enable bit banging I2C busses on the Raspberry Pi connector, up to I2C6.
